Company: American Family Life Assurance Co., known as Aflac
Description: Columbus-based American Family Life Assurance Co., known as Aflac, agreed to pay a former employee $16,882 after an investigation by the U.S. Department of Labor found that the company violated the Family and Medical Leave Act by terminating an employee who took intermittent leave for a serious health condition.
Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division

Description: Aflac agreed to pay $350,000 to settle multistate litigation regarding its use of the Social Security Administration's Death Master File.
Info Source: Two Major Insurers Agree to Death Master File Settlements Totaling $600,000, States News Service, December 20, 2017 (via Nexis).

American Family Life Assurance Company of New York (AFLAC)
Description: The Department of Financial Services entered into a consent order with American Family Life Assurance Company of New York (AFLAC), which agreed to provide restitution totaling $961,478 to New York consumers for failing to include disclosure language on premium notices in violation of New York Insurance Law and for failing to provide applicants full and clear information related to the replacement of their existing life insurance so that they could make a decision in his or her own best interest.  The insurer also paid a civil penalty of $176,890 for these violations and others discovered during a DFS market conduct examination.
Agency: New York Department of Financial Services

Description: sale of policies by unlicensed agents and other violations

Description: American Family Life Assurance agreed to pay a total of $1.6 million to insurance regulators in Minnesota, Missouri and Idaho to resolve issues relating to marketing and other matters.

Description: American Family Life Insurance Company of Columbus agreed to pay $2.5 million to insurance regulators in Idaho, Minnesota and Missouri to resolve issues relating to claims handling and other matters.
